Coronavirus Information



All correspondence and relevant information for Appleton Area School District families will be added to this page.


The safety, health, and well being of our students, staff, and community is our top priority.

Appleton Area School District Pandemic Plan

STAY SAFE DON'T SPREAD THE VIRUS

NYOB TUAB ZOO TSI XOB NTHUAV KAAB MOB

PROTÉJANSE NO TRANSMITA EL CORONAVIRUS

                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl14_divTabs_0","title":"English","content":"April 17, 2020
\n
\nAASD families,
\nEvery Friday during the state-mandated school closure, we’ll be providing an update message to families that will include relevant reminders and updates. 
\n
\nSchool and Building Closures 4/16 Update
\nOn April 16 Wisconsin's Safer at Home Order was extended until May 26. School building closures were mandated by the Governor’s office to extend through the remainder of the school year.
\n
\nDistrict Events
\nAll district and school events are cancelled or postponed through the end of the school year. This includes all spring co-curricular sports and activities.
\n
\nGraduation Celebrations for the Class of 2020
\nWe know that our Seniors are experiencing a close to their thirteen years of K - 12 education that they never could have imagined. So many well-loved traditions and gatherings have not been possible due to this health emergency. 
\n
\nPlease know that we are working with our High School principals to reach out to Seniors and their families in the near future to gather input and ideas on how to honor the graduation of the Class of 2020. We are committed to working with our students and families to find ways to celebrate this important milestone for our graduating Seniors!
\n
\nSecond Semester Grades
\nWe are in the process of gathering information from students, staff, and families regarding grading considerations for the second semester of the 19-20 school year. Please watch for a survey that will be sent out with next Friday’s family communication. Your time and effort in filling out the survey will provide important feedback for us to consider as we make the best decisions possible during this challenging time. 
\n
\nPrioritizing Social and Emotional Wellbeing
\nWe care about the social and emotional wellbeing of our students and families. We want to remind all of our families that our school counselors and social workers continue to look for the best ways to connect virtually to provide support for our students during these Distance Learning Days. When we are physically separated from one another, it’s easy to feel isolated and disconnected. Please don’t hesitate to contact your child’s school counselor, social worker or principal if you have specific concerns or requests for social and emotional support for your family. There are also many resources available on our district website. 
\n
\nState Testing 
\nThe Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI) received approval to implement waivers for requirements in section 1111 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, related to federal assessment and accountability requirements. Effective immediately, all federal testing requirements are waived for the state and all Wisconsin school districts. Due to the school closures and the evolving COVID situation, it is not possible to administer the statewide assessments for the 2019-20 school year. There will be no further state assessments this school year.
\n
\nEC-6 Distance Learning ‘Relaunch’
\nThe EC - 6 Distance Learning Plan ‘Relaunch’ that is in place for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year until June 5, 2020 has been developed to provide students with equitable learning opportunities during the extended state mandated school closure. Packets with weekly learning plans and materials were mailed to families this week. If you do not receive the mailing by early next week, please contact your child’s classroom teacher.
\n
\nClassroom teachers emailed the electronic version of the grade level packet(s) to each family on Monday, April 13, to begin the ‘relaunch’ of our Elementary Distance Learning Days.  All elementary Distance Learning plans are also available on the District website. This letter contains additional information on EC-6 Distance Learning ‘Relaunch’ Plans. This letter shares more about why i-Ready resources were discontinued.
\n
\nWe also encourage families to read through this newly added information sheet for Grade 5K-6 Distance Learning Plans for Art, Music, Physical Education, Social-Emotional Learning (SEL), and Enrichment.
\n
\n7-12 Distance Learning: After Spring Break and Beyond
\nThe 7-12 Distance Learning Plan reflects the expectations for teachers and students for continuing learning during the extended school closure until June 5, 2020. As we navigate our new environment, we are committed to ensuring all 7-12 students are provided equitable opportunities to be engaged in meaningful learning for the rest of the school year. To support our efforts, our Technology Integrators are working to put together some additional resources and support for staff as we plan for extended Distance Learning Days.
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nWe know that unequal access to technology can be a true barrier. Based on the results of our recent survey, we distributed an additional 1,200 Chromebooks to families who don’t have a device in grades K-6. We have also distributed over 350 hotspots to families without internet access in grades K-12.
\n
\nIf your family does not have internet access or does not have a device, please contact our Helpdesk and we will make arrangements. Helpdesk will be staffed from the hours of 7:30 AM - 4:00 PM. Families can reach Helpdesk through email or by phone at helpdesk@aasd.k12.wi.us or (920) 997-1399.
\n
\nStudent Belongings / Return of School Property (Chromebooks, Library books, etc.)
\nWe will schedule dates and times at the end of the school year for parents/guardians to pick up any remaining materials and personal belongings that were left at school prior to our mandated closure period. At that same time, district-issued Chromebooks and mobile hotspots will also be returned. If there are essential items that are needed prior to that time, parents/guardians should contact their school principal to make individual arrangements.
\n
\nREMINDERS
\n
\nFood Distribution: Additional Sites Added
\nBeginning Monday, April 13, 2020, the Appleton Area School District (AASD) will be providing free meals to any and all children under 18 at two additional locations, Einstein Middle School and Richmond Elementary. All AASD families are encouraged to pick-up meals at any location as often as they would like. See this post on our Food Service website for a map of locations, pick-up times, and a menu.
\n
\nSummer School Registration Postponed
\nEarlier, we shared that summer school registration opening is postponed. We want to clarify that registration for Appleton eSchool will continue as planned. We are continuing to seek guidance from the Department of Public Instruction (DPI) concerning the potential format and timing for summer school classes. Given the ongoing public health emergency, we must also consider an approach that is safe for our students, families, staff and our community.
\n
\nWe recognize that this may be the most challenging and difficult time we've gone through as a school community. Our staff and students miss each other! After all, we got into the business of education because we love working with and for our students! Our families are now being asked to oversee learning within their homes at a whole new level. And there have been so many other things that have changed as well - routines disrupted, concerts and celebrations cancelled or postponed indefinitely.
\n
\nAt times it may feel like everything is cancelled. However, all of us need to remember that connection and relationships aren’t cancelled. That the joy of learning new things to challenge ourselves isn’t cancelled. That looking for the positive in these turbulent times isn’t cancelled. That supporting each other isn’t cancelled. 
\n
\nWe are working very hard to serve all of our families and students through this ‘new normal’, and we appreciate the patience and resilience of our students, families, and staff as we adapt and innovate. We do not know what is to come, but we will face it together.
\n
\nStay safe and well,
\n
\nJudy
\n
\n\n
\nApril 3, 2020
\n\n
\nAASD families,
\nEvery Friday during the state-mandated school closure, we’ll be providing an update message to families that will include relevant reminders and updates.
\n
\nDuring this dynamic and turbulent time, the Appleton Area School District is working hard to keep a consistent focus on providing continued learning for all students. We know that distance learning cannot replace the typical school day. We also know that this is not ideal for many of our students, staff, and families. 
\n
\nWe want to support all of our families and students through this ‘new normal’, and we appreciate the patience and resilience of our students, families, and staff as we figure this out together.
\n
\nGuidelines for Learning at Home
\nWe understand that for many of our families one or both parents may still be working outside the home and that families are providing care for young siblings or another family member and that an eight hour school day is not feasible. We want to provide guidelines and encouragement to our families who are navigating this right along with us. 
\n
\nWe encourage our 3 - 6-grade families to consider that the ratio of two hours of distance learning relates to eight hours of school time. For grades 5K - 2, the ratio can be reduced to 1.5 hours. This learning at home time does not have to be continuous (i.e. student sitting at a computer for a specific number of minutes). 
\n
\nStudents in grades 7 - 12 should be engaged in learning activities 3 hours per day throughout all of their classes (not 3 hours of work per class per day).  Spring break might be a great time for students who have fallen behind to get ahead in their previously assigned Distance Learning responsibilities.
\n
\nEC-6 Distance Learning ‘Relaunch’
\nThe first phase of our Distance Learning planning for Early-Childhood (EC) - grade 6 was primarily driven through learning packets and books that were sent home on March 16, 2020, our last day in school buildings. 
\n
\nAs the state-mandated closures have continued, we have now created an EC - 6 Distance Learning Plan ‘Relaunch’ for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. This long-term plan has been developed to support the continuity of learning for our students and to assure equity of access to technology in the home. 
\n
\nWe know that unequal access to technology can be a true barrier for families. In order to address these digital access and equity concerns, we have completed a phone survey of all 5K-6 families to determine levels of need. Based on the results of this phone survey, we will be delivering AASD Chromebooks and hot-spots as needed to fill digital access gaps. Please see this letter that contains more details on our EC-6 Distance Learning ‘Relaunch’ Plans.
\n
\n7-12 Distance Learning: After Spring Break and Beyond
\nOur 7-12 Distance Learning Plan was implemented on Wednesday, March 18th. Although we originally anticipated an approximate 2-week school closure, the plan reflects the expectations for teachers and students for continuing learning during the extended school closure dates. It was designed to provide students with relevant, meaningful, grade-appropriate learning experiences.   
\n
\nWe appreciate that each student/family is affected by this school closure situation in different ways.  As we navigate our new environment, we are committed to ensuring all 7-12 students are provided equitable opportunities to be engaged in meaningful learning for the duration of the school closure. To support our efforts, our Technology Integrators are working to put together some additional resources and support for staff as we plan for extended Distance Learning Days.
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nIf you don’t have any access to the internet at home, please contact Technology Services at (920) 997-1399. They will make arrangements for you to get a mobile “hotspot.”
\n
\nSummer School Registration Postponed
\nLast week we shared that summer school registration opening is postponed. We want to clarify that registration for Appleton eSchool will continue as planned.
\n
\nREMINDERS
\n
\nFood Distribution: Additional Sites Added
\nBeginning Monday, March 30, 2020, the AASD will be providing free meals to students in need at six additional locations. For times, addresses, menus, and pick-up locations, see this post on our Food Service website.
\n
\nSchool and Building Closures
\nSchools will continue to be closed for the duration of the public health emergency.  Safer at Home guidelines specify that school closures will be in place at least until April 24th and potentially longer, or until a superseding order is issued. 
\n
\nDistrict Events
\nWe have cancelled or postponed all district events until further notice. We will reassess future cancellations closer to April 24 and provide updates to families, as needed.
\n
\nIn closing, I would like to thank all of you for your partnership with us in keeping our focus on the essential things, especially during this challenging health emergency.  In my mind, these essentials are safety and wellness, strong connections with students, families and staff and continued, equitable learning for all.
\n
\nPlease note, during the upcoming Spring Break (April 4 - April 12), the AASD will be closed and staff will not be available to respond to calls or emails during this time period. Please take advantage of this much-needed break from Distance Learning Days to enjoy some fresh air and sunshine with your family. 
\n
\nStay safe and well,
\n
\nJudy
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 27, 2020
\n\n
\nDear Appleton Area School District Families,
\n
\nEvery Friday during the state-mandated school closure, we’ll be providing an update message to families that will include relevant reminders and updates. Communication is even more important when times are uncertain and situations are changing rapidly. 
\n
\nSafer at Home Order
\nGovernor Evers’ 'Safer at Home' order is in effect from March 25 through April 24. All Wisconsin residents are asked to STAY HOME, unless on essential business. Please remind your children of the important role they play in reducing the spread of COVID-19 and eliminate all in-person contacts with friends.  Per Governor Evers, this means, \"no sleepovers, no playdates, and no dinner parties with friends and neighbors\".  It is OK to go for a walk, ride your bike, and walk the dog. Just be sure you are at least 6 feet away from other people. Thank you and stay healthy!
\n
\nSummer School Registration Postponed
\nThe scheduled March 30 summer school registration opening is postponed. We will provide an update soon.
\n
\nStrings Festival Cancelled
\nIt is with great sadness that we announce the cancellation of our AASD Strings Festival, previously scheduled to be held at the Fox Cities Performing Arts Center (PAC) on Tuesday, April 21, 2020 at 7:00 p.m. 
\n
\nWith the uncertainty of the current situation in our state, the limit on large gatherings of people, and the inability of our students to rehearse in large groups during the school closures, this seemed like the best decision to make at this time. Keep practicing!
\n
\nGraduation Planning for Seniors
\nWe are working through this important topic and will continue to provide opportunities aligned to students’ current schedules for completing the necessary credits. In addition, we will continue to work with students who need to recover credits that are required for graduation. We understand what an enormous impact this prolonged school closure has had on our Seniors and their families.  Please know that it is our plan to provide a meaningful graduation celebration for all when the health emergency has passed. 
\n
\nFood Distribution: Additional Sites Added
\nBeginning Monday, March 30, 2020, the AASD will be providing free meals to students in need at six additional locations. Free meals can be picked up at Kaleidoscope Academy, Madison Middle School, Wilson Middle School, Badger Elementary, Columbus Elementary, Highlands Elementary, Horizons Elementary, Jefferson Elementary, and Johnston Elementary, Monday through Friday. 
\n
\nFor times, addresses, menus, and pick-up locations, see this post on our Food Service website.
\n
\nFree meals will also now be available Monday through Thursday of spring break week (April 6-9). Two days of meals will be distributed on April 9.
\n
\nPick-up locations will be set up so families do not need to enter the school to receive meals. All meals will be served in a “grab and go” fashion and will include milk. Meals will include a pre-packaged lunch for the current day, and pre-packed breakfast for the next day.
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nAASD Tech Services has received its first shipment of mobile “hotspots.” If you have a student that is in grades 7-12 and you don’t have any access to the internet at home, please contact Technology Services at (920) 997-1399. They will make arrangements for you to get a mobile “hotspot.”
\n
\nREMINDERS
\n
\nSchool and Building Closures
\nOn March 13, Governor Evers ordered public schools closed until April 6, but due to the community spread of the COVID-19 virus in the state, on March 17,  he announced schools would be closed for the duration of the public health emergency.  Now, with the Safer at Home provisions in place until April 24th, we know that the school closures will be in place at least until April 24th and potentially longer, or until a superseding order is issued. We are planning forward to accommodate an extended Distance Learning time frame, if needed.
\n
\nDistrict Events
\nWe have cancelled or postponed all district events until further notice. We will reassess future cancellations closer to April 24 and provide updates to families, as needed.
\n
\nDistance Learning
\nAll Early Childhood-Grade 6 Distance Learning resources are currently available on the District website. Classroom teachers will be contacting families weekly to check on student progress and to answer any questions. These resources will be updated to accommodate Distance Learning following spring break.
\n
\nThe Middle/High School Distance Learning Plan has been designed to provide students with relevant and appropriate learning experiences at home to ensure that students keep up and even build their skills. All teachers will either be using Google Classroom or Canvas as the online tool for delivering instruction through the student Chromebook.  
\n
\nAs we continue to navigate through the challenges of school closures and the COVID-19 pandemic, I have been brought to a place of seeking the ‘essentials’ for our district and for myself personally. 
\n
\nBack in the early 2000’s, AASD held our Welcome Back gathering for all staff in the gym at East High School (nothing like 3 hours on bleachers in a gym to create a strong memory). The keynote speaker that day used a jar, sand, small pebbles and rocks to share an analogy that has stayed with me through the years. 
\n
\nHis message was that if we focus on the ‘big rocks’ first, everything else will follow. Earlier this week, one of our team members took it to another level for us by calling up the image of BOULDERS rather than just big rocks. I agree, now more than ever, let’s focus on the boulders – the essential things that really matter – the rest will follow.
\n
\nThank you for your continued support and partnership.
\n
\nDr. Judith Baseman
\nSuperintendent
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 20, 2020
\n
\nDear Appleton Area School District Families,
\n
\nWe greatly appreciate your support and patience as we continue to navigate this rapidly changing and complex situation.  Your willingness to partner with us to support learning for your student(s) has always been an extremely important part of student success. Now, our strong partnership with you is more essential than ever.
\n
\nEvery Friday during the state-mandated school closure, we’ll be providing an update message to families that will include relevant reminders and updates. 
\n
\nSchool and Facilities Closures
\nOn March 13, Governor Evers ordered public schools closed until April 6, but due to the community spread of the COVID-19 virus in the state, on March 17 he announced schools would be closed for the duration of the public health emergency.
\n
\nWe are making every effort to protect our students and our staff during this public health emergency. Effective March 18, 2020, AASD staff members are working remotely to ensure all essential functions will continue. All of our school buildings, as well as the District Leadership Center, will be closed until further notice. 
\n
\nHowever, email and voicemail messages will be monitored and returned in a timely manner and essential functions will be maintained to support our staff, students, and families. In addition, teachers are in regular contact with their students to support Distance Learning. This includes all students, Early Childhood through 12. Our student services team is also working to support our families and students beyond academics.
\n
\nWe have cancelled or postponed all district events until further notice. We will reassess these practices prior to the AASD Spring Break (April 6 - 10)  and provide updates to families, as needed.
\n
\nFood Distribution
\nThe AASD is providing free meals to students in need while schools are closed due to COVID-19. Free meals will also be available during the AASD scheduled spring break, April 6 through April 10. 
\n
\nPick-up locations are set up so families do not need to enter the school to receive meals. Families should drive up near the door and the items will be brought out. If there is inclement weather, the driver can still drive up, get out to come up to the  door and get the number of meals they need.
\n
\nAll meals are served in a “grab and go” fashion and include milk. Meals include a pre-packaged lunch for the current day and a pre-packed breakfast for the next day. Be sure to keep foods safe by placing the extra milk in the refrigerator when arriving home.
\n
\nKaleidoscope Academy 318 E. Brewster St.
\nMonday-Friday from 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM
\nDoor D – front of building
\n
\nMadison Middle School 2020 S. Carpenter St.
\nMonday-Friday from 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM
\nDoor G – Back side of building
\n
\nWilson Middle School 225 N. Badger Ave.
\nMonday-Friday from 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM
\nDoor Q – Access from north parking lot
\n
\nFind other community resources and supports on our website.
\n
\nDistance Learning
\nAll Early Childhood-Grade 6 Distance Learning resources are currently available on the District website. Classroom teachers will be contacting families to check on student progress and to answer any questions.
\n
\nThe Middle/High School Distance Learning Plan has been designed to provide students with relevant and appropriate learning experiences at home to ensure that students keep up and even build their skills. All teachers will either be using Google Classroom or Canvas as the online tool for delivering instruction through the student Chromebook. Courses that are currently using Canvas will continue to use Canvas as the online platform. Courses that have not yet been using Canvas will use Google Classroom as the online platform.
\n
\nIf your student does not have internet access at home, please know that we are working on acquiring wireless ‘hotspots’ that could assist you. We will share more on this in the coming days.
\n
\nThese are truly unprecedented times and we're learning right alongside our families and community as we navigate this together. We are so proud of our staff who are taking this challenge on. We are also extremely grateful to our students and families who are working together to support learning opportunities at home.
\n
\nAs the situation continues to evolve, we may need to adapt, but through it all we will lead through the lens of our shared vision and commitment to Success for Every Student Every Day.
\n
\nThank you for your continued support and partnership.
\n
\nGratefully,
\n
\nDr. Judith Baseman
\nSuperintendent
\n
\nAs information continues to develop quickly, families are encouraged to continue to visit the District’s Coronavirus webpage.
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 19, 2020
\n\n
\nWe are happy to share that we will be providing our free meals without interruption over the AASD scheduled spring break from April 6 through April 10.
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 16, 2020
\n
\nBeginning Tuesday, March 17, 2020, the Appleton Area School District (AASD) will be providing free meals to students in need while schools are closed due to COVID-19.  
\n
\nFree meals can be picked up at the following locations (see below), Monday through Friday, at the times indicated starting Tuesday, March 17, 2020. Free meals will not be available during AASD scheduled spring break, April 6 through April 10.
\n
\nPick-up locations will be set up so families do not need to enter the school to receive meals.
\n•\tAll meals will be served in a “grab and go” fashion and will include milk.
\n•\tMeals will include a pre-packaged lunch for the current day, and prepacked breakfast for the next day. 
\n
\nIMPORTANT: Meal pick-up times and details may be adjusted as needs are evaluated.
\n
\nSchool Closure Menu
\n
\nKaleidoscope Academy\t
\n318 E. Brewster St.\t
\n11:00 AM – 1:00 PM\t
\nDoor D – front of building
\n
\nMadison Middle School\t
\n2020 S. Carpenter St.\t
\n11:00 AM – 1:00 PM\t
\nDoor G – Back side of building
\n
\nWilson Middle School\t
\n225 N. Badger Ave.\t
\n11:00 AM – 1:00 PM\t
\nDoor Q – Access from north parking lot
\n 
\nThe AASD recognizes that many students rely on the Free and Reduced Meal Program at their school and is committed to continuing to meet the needs of all students.  Please continue to visit the AASD website for the latest news and updates amid the COVID-19 school closure.  
\n
\nDr. Judith Baseman
\nSuperintendent 
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 15, 2020
\n
\nDear Appleton Area School District Families,
\n
\nAs we continue to navigate through these challenging times for our community and state, I want to update you regarding our upcoming school closure due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 
\n
\nPlease be reminded that beginning Tuesday, March 17, the Appleton Area School District (AASD) schools will be closed until further notice. This includes before and after school Extended Day Learning and all school clubs, activities, and events. 
\n
\nWe will be working with Chartwells, our school meal provider, to offer free meals to students in need while our schools are closed. This service will begin on Tuesday, March 17, at three school district distribution sites - Kaleidoscope Academy, Madison Middle School, and Wilson Middle School. More details regarding distribution will be forthcoming tomorrow morning.
\n
\nTomorrow, Monday, March 16, 2020, will be a normal school day. Plans are in place to provide Distance Learning at home for students during the school closure, following the schedule below:
\n
\nMarch 16 \t\tSchool in session - regular school day with before/after school programming
\nMarch 17 \t\tNo School for Students; Staff Preparation Day
\nMarch 18  \t\tNo School for Students; Staff Preparation Day
\nMarch 19-April 3 \tDistance Learning Days for Students
\nApril 6-April10  \tAASD Closed - Spring Break
\nApril 13th \t\tTo be Determined
\n
\nMedications and Health Related Items
\nIf your student receives daily or as needed medication at school or if your student keeps other health-related items at school (such as for tube feeding, catheterization, diabetes, etc.) and you will need them during the school closure, please stop at the school office on Monday, March 16, or Tuesday, March 17, between 7:30 AM-4:00 PM, to pick them up.  We are unable to send medication home with students. Parents will not be able to retrieve medications or health related items from school once school buildings close. 
\n
\nSpeaking to Your Student About COVID-19
\nWe know that you may be concerned and worried about this public health emergency. We’ve provided some resources below about how to speak to your student:
\n
\nTalking to Children About COVID-19 (Coronavirus): A Parent Resource from the National Association of School Psychologists (also available in Spanish)
\n
\nTalking With Children: Tips For Caregivers, Parents, and Teachers During Infectious Disease Outbreaks from the National Association of School Psychologists
\n
\nDistance Learning Plans
\nThe following are the Distance Learning Plans in place during the upcoming school closure in the AASD.
\n
\nPlease Note: If your student attends a charter school in the AASD, you may be receiving additional and/or alternative plans for your student.
\n
\nAppleton Community 4K Distance Learning Plan
\nA Distance Learning Instructional Kit will be sent home with each 4K student tomorrow.  The Learning Kit will include a Family Unit of Study Guide that provides daily and weekly learning activities in our 4K curriculum areas of early literacy, writing, social and emotional development, math, and fine/gross motor movement. In early learning, children learn best by interacting with their environment, peers and teachers. The Distance Learning Kit includes activities with “I can” statements that show what your child is learning from the 4K curriculum when engaged in each of these play activities. 
\n
\nYour 4K student’s teacher will be contacting you on Tuesday, March 17, or Wednesday, March 18, to review the Distance Learning materials sent home and answer any questions.  Please use the bag provided for storage of your student’s instructional materials while at home, and send the materials back to school in the bag when school resumes again. 
\n
\nIf your 4K student is unable to be in school on Monday, please make arrangements to stop at your child’s 4K location on Tuesday, March 17, between 8:00 AM-3:30 PM, to pick up your students Distance Learning materials. 
\n
\nK-6 (Elementary) Distance Learning Plan
\n\nThe K-6 Distance Learning Plan has been designed to provide students with relevant and appropriate learning experiences at home to ensure students keep up and even build their skills.  Your child will return home from school tomorrow with a recommended daily Distance Learning schedule and a bag of materials that focus on literacy and mathematics:
\n
\nLiteracy- We created a parent/student-friendly literacy plan for students to simply read and write based on the recommended number of minutes children should be reading in school each day and the number of books students should be reading based on book level.
\n
\nMathematics- The materials were designed to provide students with interactive methods to review the key learning for their grade level.  Each packet includes inquiry activities, games, and review problems to help further develop a student’s math skills while they are away from school. 
\n
\nIf your K-6 student(s) will not be at school on Monday, please make arrangements to stop at the school office on Tuesday, March 17, between 7:30 AM - 4:00 PM, to pick up your student(s) Distance Learning materials.
\n
\nYour K-6 student’s teacher will be contacting you on Tuesday, March 17, or Wednesday, March 18, to review the Distance Learning materials sent home and answer any questions. Please use the bag provided for storage of your student’s instructional materials while at home, and send the materials back to school in the bag when school resumes again. 
\n
\nK-6 Distance Learning materials for other instructional areas such as Art, Music, Physical Education, Band, Orchestra, Talented and Gifted, and Social and Emotional Learning are also being developed. Some may be included in your student’s book bag on Monday.  
\n
\nAll K-6 Distance Learning materials will be available on the District’s Coronavirus webpage no later than Thursday, March 19.  
\n
\nMiddle and High School Distance Learning Plan 
\nThe middle and high school Distance Learning Plan has been designed to provide students with relevant and appropriate learning experiences at home to ensure that students keep up and even build their skills.  All teachers will either be using Google Classroom or Canvas as the online tool for delivering instruction through the student Chromebook.
\n
\nCourses that are currently using Canvas will continue to use Canvas as the online platform.
\nCourses that have not yet been using Canvas will use Google Classroom as the online platform.
\n
\nPlease note: 
\n\nPlease click this link for additional information on the middle and high school Distance Learning Plan.
\n
\nIf your student does not have internet access at home, please know that we are working on acquiring wireless ‘hotspots’ that could assist you. You also may qualify for discounted internet services.
\n
\nEducator Availability During School Closure
\n\nEducators will be available via email on Distance Learning Days, Monday-Friday, to support student learning and answer parent/guardian questions at the following times: 9:00 - 11:30 AM and 1:30 - 3:00 PM. Educator email addresses are available on each school’s website under Our School - Staff Directory.
\n
\nYour support and patience as we navigate this rapidly changing and complex situation is greatly appreciated. We look forward to having our students back at school with us as soon as it is safely possible!
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nDr. Judith M. Baseman
\nSuperintendent of Schools
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 13, 2020 (5:15 p.m.)
\n\n
\nAppleton Area School District Families,
\n
\nLate this afternoon, Governor Evers directed that all public and private 4K-12 schools are mandated to shut down by Wednesday, March 18.
\n
\nBeginning Tuesday, March 17, the Appleton Area School District will close until further notice. This includes the before and after school extended day learning program, athletics/co-curriculars, etc. 
\n
\nMonday, March 16, will be a normal school day. All 4K-12 students will be sent home with belongings and instructional materials. 
\n
\nPlans will be in place to provide distance learning at home for students during the school closure as per the schedule below:
\nMarch 16th - School in session - regular school day with before and after school programming
\nMarch 17th - No School for Students; Staff Preparation Day
\nMarch 18th - No School for Students; Staff Preparation Day
\nWeeks of March 19th through April 3rd - Distance Learning Days for Students begin on March 19th
\nWeek of April 6th - April 10th  - AASD closed - Spring Break
\nWeek of April 13th - To be determined
\n
\nThe District, along with Chartwells, our food service provider, will have an emergency food distribution plan ready to put into place within approximately one week. More information will be forthcoming; we encourage you to check the District’s Coronavirus webpage for updates.
\n
\nThe health and safety of our students and staff are our highest priority and we will continue to work with our City of Appleton Health Officer to do what is needed to keep our students and staff safe. We will continue to communicate with staff and families as we have new information.
\n
\nJudith Baseman
\nSuperintendent
\nAppleton Area School District
\n\nMarch 13, 2020 - Yesterday, Governor Evers declared a public health emergency for the State of Wisconsin. We communicated with you regarding some of the immediate precautionary actions we have put into place as a district to disrupt the spread of COVID-19. These actions were taken as a result of a direct recommendation from the Governor of Wisconsin and/or recommendations from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and/or the Centers for Disease Control.
\n
\nAt this time, there are still no confirmed cases of COVID-19 within the AASD.
\n
\nWe know that our families have a lot of questions; please bear with us as we navigate through this rapidly changing and complex situation. See below to learn how the AASD is responding to the COVID-19 pandemic.
\n
\nTravel (Please see full prior communication to all families sent 3/12 below)
\nWe are taking preventive measures by implementing a temporary travel restriction on any and all non-essential district-related/sponsored staff and student travel effective Monday, March 16, 2020. This restriction includes district-related/sponsored travel for meetings, conferences, field trips or any other events both in and out of the state of Wisconsin (with the exception of travel within the Fox Cities). These travel restrictions will be in place until further notice. 
\n
\nEvents (Please see the full prior communication to all families sent 3/12 below)
\nGovernor Evers declared a public health emergency on March 12 in the state of Wisconsin in response to the COVID-19 outbreak and recommended canceling events where large groups of 250 or more people would be gathering. As a district, we are following these recommendations to prevent the spread of this virus in our community, which includes older adults and people with underlying medical conditions who are at a higher risk. We are canceling or postponing large events of 250 people or more in the district, effective March 12. This includes plays, musical performances, and other events where large crowds would be expected. For confirmation of an event’s cancellation, please see your school’s website calendar or call the school office. These precautionary measures will remain in place until further notice. We will continue to monitor and provide updates as additional information becomes available. As we move forward, we will share with families if there is an opportunity for any performances or events to be rescheduled.
\n
\nSchool Closure
\nAlong with the above precautions, we are also preparing for the possibility of school closure. The health and safety of our students and staff are our highest priority and we will continue to work with our City of Appleton Health Officer to determine if/when school closure is needed to keep our students and staff safe.
\n
\nWe know that closing 4K-12 schools would impact all of our families, including our most vulnerable families. We also know that all of our families depend upon the consistency and predictability of the supports and services that our schools offer.  Per Governor Evers’ address on March 12, unless there is an outbreak in our community, schools are to remain open due to the essential functions, services and supports they provide our students and our families.  
\n
\nTherefore, AASD will remain open until further notice.
\n
\nHowever, in preparation for a potential school closure, a multi-disciplinary team has been meeting to coordinate continued learning if schools were ordered to close. We are also planning for the possibility of food distribution sites for families in need.
\n
\nAt this time, the Department of Public Instruction is still requiring school districts to maintain the same hours and minutes of instruction for students. Our team is preparing materials and online learning opportunities to help us meet these requirements, should we need to close our schools. More details about these opportunities will be forthcoming for families should school closure become necessary.
\n
\nExcused Absences
\nWe encourage our families to make the decision that is right for their student(s) and family in regard to school attendance during this public health emergency. We encourage you to consult with your healthcare provider for their recommendations if you feel your student is at greater risk for contracting the COVID-19 virus. Your school nurse can also serve as a resource.
\n
\nIf you decide to keep your student home please know that the following absence reasons will be excused: 
\n•\tIf a student has been recommended/required to self-isolate per a healthcare provider or Centers for Disease Control (CDC) guidelines. 
\n•\tIf a student is absent due to general concerns around COVID-19. 
\n•\tIf a student is at high risk or part of a special population (as identified by the Centers for Disease Control [CDC]) and is absent due to COVID-19.
\n
\nAt this time, we are following our current student attendance policy regarding missed work. We ask that students and/or parents reach out to their teacher(s) to make arrangements for making up work missed during an absence from school.
\n
\nCo-Curriculars / Extended Day Learning Program / Afterschool Activities
\nAt this time, we are continuing to offer our Extended Day Learning Programs in collaboration with the YMCA and the Boys and Girls Club.  Co-curricular practices, groups, and clubs will also continue to meet at our schools, as long as the gathering meets the guidelines of 250 people or less. We will continue to monitor the situation and consult with our local and state health officials to determine if a change in this protocol is needed.
\n
\nParent-Teacher Conferences
\nAny upcoming Parent-Teacher conferences will be held ‘in person’ at our schools this spring. However, parents may request to hold conferences via phone rather than face to face with families. More information regarding your student’s conference can be obtained by contacting your student’s school and/or visiting your school’s website.
\n
\nCleaning
\nThe District has increased daily cleaning protocols, with our custodial staff cleaning high-frequency areas periodically throughout the school day.
\n
\nPrevention
\nThe best ways to avoid contracting COVID-19:
\n•\tWash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
\n•\tAvoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
\n•\tAvoid close contact with people who are sick
\n•\tCover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, and cough/sneeze into your elbow
\n
\nIf you develop symptoms:
\n•\tStay home; do not go to work, school or public areas
\n•\tSeparate yourself from people in your home
\n•\tAvoid sharing personal household items
\n•\tWash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
\n•\tClean “high-touch” surfaces every day
\n•\tAvoid using public transportation
\n
\nSpeaking to your student about COVID-19
\nWe know that our families are concerned and worried about this public health emergency. We’ve provided some resources below about how to speak to your students.
\n
\nTalking to Children About COVID-19 (Coronavirus): A Parent Resource from the National Association of School Psychologists (also available in Spanish)
\nTalking With Children: Tips For Caregivers, Parents, and Teachers During Infectious Disease Outbreaks from the National Association of School Psychologists
\n
\nWe also want to remind our families of the HOPELINE resource. It is a text-in (versus voice call-in) free emotional support service providing hope, help, and support when it’s needed most. HOPELINE serves anyone in any type of situation providing them access to free, 24/7 emotional support and information they need via the medium they already use and trust: text. HOPELINE’s purpose is to offer emotional support and resources before situations rise to crisis level. Hopeline can be reached by texting 741741.
\n
\nWe appreciate the support and patience of our families as we navigate this rapidly changing and complex situation. We will continue to communicate with staff and families as we have new information.
\n
\nJudith Baseman
\nSuperintendent
\nAppleton Area School District
\n\nMarch 13, 2020 - The health and safety of our students, staff, families, and volunteers are a top priority. Therefore as a district, we are following recommendations to prevent the spread of this virus in our community. We will pause our volunteer tutoring programs, the United for Reading Success and Math Achievement Program, effective Monday, March 16, 2020 until further notice. We will continue to monitor and provide updates as more information becomes available. 
\n
\n\nMarch 12, 2020 - The safety, health, and wellbeing of our students, staff, and community is our top priority. As of today, Governor Evers declared a public health emergency in the state of Wisconsin in response to the COVID-19 outbreak. We are taking preventive measures by implementing a temporary travel restriction on any and all non-essential district-related/sponsored staff and student travel effective Monday, March 16, 2020.
\n
\nThis restriction includes district-related/sponsored travel for meetings, conferences, field trips or any other events both in and out of the state of Wisconsin (with the exception of travel within the Fox Cities). These travel restrictions will be in place until further notice. We will continue to monitor and provide updates as information becomes available.
\n
\nAppleton Area School District administrators and staff will continue to monitor the Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak locally, state-wide, across the country, and globally. At this time, there have been six confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Wisconsin.
\n
\nIt is also being reported that in each of these recent cases there was a history of domestic travel. Public health officials are still indicating that while the risk to our area remains relatively low, they are recommending to stop non-essential travel, especially in areas where there is community spread of the virus. We are receiving our guidance from the local and state health officials as well as the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).  
\n
\nIt is important to note that this is a time of preparation in support of keeping our students, staff and community safe and healthy. As information continues to develop quickly, parents and staff are encouraged to continue to visit the District’s Coronavirus webpage. We will continue to communicate with staff and families as we have new information. 
\n
\nThank you for your time and understanding.
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 12, 2020 - Today Governor Evers declared a public health emergency in the state of Wisconsin in response to the COVID-19 outbreak. The Governor also recommended cancelling events where large groups of 250 or more people would be gathering.
\n
\nAs a district, we are following these recommendations to prevent the spread of this virus in our community, including older adults and people with underlying medical conditions who are at a higher risk. Therefore, based on Governor Evers’ recommendation, we will be postponing large events of 250 people or more in the district. This is effective immediately. This includes plays, musical performances, and other events where large crowds would be expected. The health and safety of our students, staff, and families are a top priority.
\n
\nFor confirmation of an event’s cancellation, please see your school’s website calendar or call the school office.
\n
\nThese precautionary measures will remain in place until further notice. As we move forward, we will share with families if there is an opportunity for any performances or events to be rescheduled.
\n
\nAppleton Area School District administrators and staff will continue to monitor the Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak locally, state-wide, across the country, and globally.
\n
\nAs information continues to develop quickly, parents and staff are encouraged to continue to visit the District’s Coronavirus webpage. We will continue to communicate with staff and families as we have new information.
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 11, 2020 -We are discussing our response to upcoming planned district-related travel events for students and staff. We are working in collaboration with Kurt Eggebrecht, our Appleton City Health Official, and are looking at the guidelines that are given to us by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) as well as the Wisconsin DPI, and the Department of Health and Human Services.
\n
\nOur most recent information from these sources recommends that individuals self-quarantine upon returning from countries with a Level 2 or Level 3 travel health notice from the CDC. Currently, we have not been notified of any restrictions on domestic travel.
\n
\nWe are carefully watching this situation as it develops and are prepared to communicate with all stakeholders. If the recommendations change from any of these organizations or if community spread would reach levels of concern, we would consider restricting district-related travel events and communicate next steps accordingly.
\n
\n\n
\nMarch 5, 2020 - As you are aware, the Coronavirus, now known as COVID-19, has continued to take shape in the national news and most recently, local news outlets. Recent conversations with City of Appleton Health officials regarding the current state of COVID-19 in Wisconsin have taken place, and, although a rapidly changing environment, the risk level in Wisconsin is low at this time. 
\n
\nCity of Appleton Health Officer, Kurt Eggebrecht, is being updated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Wisconsin Department of Health Services continues to provide our school district with recommendations and up-to-date information to promote a safe environment for all school district stakeholders.
\n
\nThe most current information regarding COVID-19 can be found on the district’s website with links to valuable information and resources from the CDC and the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI). Also, for your convenience, we’ve attached a resource.
\n
\nAs we continue to monitor the developments regarding this virus, we will continue to look to national, state, and local health agencies for guidance as we navigate and learn more about COVID-19 and its possible impact on our district and community. Given the uniqueness of each community and their needs, the response may look different from each community in order to meet those needs.
\n
\nAgain, as reported by the CDC, the “risk to the general public is low” at this time, and there are no actions specific to COVID-19 beyond normal prevention recommendations that include:
\n
\n• Covering your cough or sneeze
\n• Washing your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or using an alcohol-based hand rub if soap is not available
\n• Staying at home if you are sick
\n• Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe
\n• Getting your flu shot. Influenza also remains highly active in our area and there is still time to receive a flu shot by contacting your doctor or local pharmacy
\n
\nWe will continue to monitor the situation, and we will certainly provide any necessary updates as we learn of them. The safety and well-being of our students and staff remain our utmost priority.
\n
\n\n
\nFebruary 26, 2020 - We wanted to share with our families that we continue to work closely with the Health Department of the City of Appleton on this situation. They regularly receive up to date, global information and data related to the COVID-19 virus and are in frequent contact with both state and national agencies.
\n
\nWe have a strong history of working closely and effectively with the Appleton City Health Department to keep our students, staff and families safe, healthy, and informed. 
\n
\nWe will continue to be transparent with our families and community and will share any relevant updates related to COVID19 at this location and/or through more direct communication, as needed.
\n
\nAt this time there are no recommendations related to COVID-19 beyond:
\n
\n - Stay at home when you are sick
\n - Wash hands thoroughly and often
\n - Cover your cough and dispose of tissues
\n - Follow public health recommendations if you have an ill household member
\n
\n\n
\nFebruary 20, 2020 - There has been much in the news regarding the new virus called COVID-19 and we continue to learn more as time goes on. To help us stay current we reached out to the Appleton Health Department to ask a few questions about this emerging health issue. 
\n
\nWe want to share with you what we learned and encourage you to contact Appleton Health Department at 832-6429 should you have additional questions.
\n
\nWhat if one of my students/staff recently visited China. Can they come to school?
\n
\n• Healthy people who have visited China and were in the U.S. before February 3, 2020, can go to school as they normally would.
\n
\n• If you have students or staff returning from China on or after February 3, 2020, public health staff will be notified by CDC, and will determine what level of precaution is needed for that person. Public health staff may advise that they stay home from school or work and take other precautions for a period of time after they return, even if they are well.
\n
\n• Although precautions are necessary to prevent the entry and spread of COVID-19 into US communities, care should be taken to avoid stigmatizing students and staff who may have been exposed to the virus. Schools offer a welcoming, respectful, inclusive, and supportive environment to all and should continue to do so.
\n
\nWhat if one of my students/staff had contact with someone who visited China. Can they come to school?
\n
\nState and local public health authorities are contacting people in Wisconsin who may have been exposed to COVID-19 based on guidance from the CDC, and those individuals are given specific instructions about whether they can go to school or work. Schools do not need to make that determination on their own. Unless your students/staff have been told by public health authorities to stay home from school because of their specific risk assessment, they do not need to be restricted from school.
\n
\nWould I need to contact public health if I have a student returning from China?
\n• No, current travelers from China are being routed through certain airports where they are screened for symptoms.
\n
\n• If travelers have symptoms and were recently in China, they will not be allowed to travel further. If they do not have symptoms, they will travel to their final destination. State and local health authorities will receive contact information of people within their jurisdiction who have recently traveled from China and will follow-up with them to monitor symptoms and ensure they are staying home, if necessary.
\n
\nWhat is being done to keep us safe?
\n
\nCurrently, the risk of COVID-19 to the general public in Wisconsin is very low. That said, public health authorities at the federal, state, and local levels are working around the clock to reduce the risk to the public. We are working to quickly identify and test anyone who may be infected to ensure they receive the appropriate level of care, and are isolated to prevent any additional transmission. 
\n
\nWe are also coordinating with CDC to identify travelers from affected areas of the world and ensure they are screened for symptoms and are monitored appropriately in case they develop symptoms.
\n
\nWhat can you do to help if you have a student who is being asked to stay home from school by public health? 
\n
\nTo reduce the impact of this request on students who are asked to stay home from school, public health may ask that schools make reasonable accommodations to allow these students to continue their studies remotely and/or make-up missed lessons or assignments, in accordance with your school district's attendance policy.
\n
\nFor additional information about COVID-19 click here.
